p: As such, scarcity discourse could potentially give rise to post-politicisation (‘scarcity of politics’) in which democratic politics are replaced by techno-managerial planning or governance by expert administrators (Swyngedouw 2013). Under post-political conditions, the policy debate is largely confined within the purview of managerial adjustments such as the choice of technologies and the timing of their implementation; normative and ideological questions are sidelined. This is how national governments in western democracy responded to the coronavirus pandemic crisis—and it could be repeated for addressing the climate crisis (Hulme et al. 2020).
